post: A petition has been created to appeal the Tory Lanez verdict immediately https://t.co/sRHXxm3f4D
community_notes:
In a civil case, either party may appeal to a higher court. In a criminal case, only the defendant has a right to an appeal in most states. A public change.org petition may demonstrate support for Tory Lanez, however, it is not a legal process. 
https://www.americanbar.org/groups/public_education/resources/law_related_education_network/how_courts_work/appeals/#:~:text=In%20a%20civil%20case%2C%20either,an%20appeal%20in%20most%20states.
LLM_notes: The post claims a petition to immediately appeal the Tory Lanez verdict has been created, but this is inaccurate. Petitions do not overrule court decisions or start appeals; appeals require a motion from the lawyer after his January sentencing, and there are only a small number of signatures, which won’t affect the legal process. The legal system doesn’t work through digital petitions, and he may not qualify for a free appellate lawyer, so the petition won’t lead to an immediate appeal.
label: P

The actual charges include more serious crimes, like 2nd degree rape of a minor, sexual battery of minors under 13, filming a minor in a bath (child pornography), and producing pornography involving children under 13, not just the cupcakes.

post: I think Rishi Sunak said today at PMQs that the UK economy grew as much as the German economy last year. This is not true. The German economy grew by 1.9%, the UK economy grew by 0.5%. Besides that the German economy is larger than the UK economy.
community_notes:
The 0.5% UK growth figure used here, appears to be the monthly growth figure, for Oct 2022 compared to Sept 2022.
https://www.ons.gov.uk/economy/grossdomesticproductgdp/bulletins/gdpmonthlyestimateuk/october2022

The 1.9% German growth figure used is the growth for the whole of 2022 compared to 2021.
https://www.destatis.de/EN/Press/2023/01/PE23_037_811.html

This is not the same.

UK growth for 2022 is projected to be 4.1%.
https://www.imf.org/en/Blogs/Articles/2023/01/30/global-economy-to-slow-further-amid-signs-of-resilience-and-china-re-opening
LLM_notes: The post's claim that Rishi Sunak said the UK economy grew as much as Germany's last year is inaccurate. Economists note this is misleading because it doesn't account for faster UK population growth, and GDP per capita (which determines living standards) is actually slower in the UK. Additionally, the UK economy is now smaller relative to Germany than in 2016, dropping from 90% of Germany's size to 70%. Germany is also more exposed to energy price impacts due to its larger industrial output and past reliance on Russian gas, and its economy is larger with better living standards.
label: T

post:
Under my predecessor, the deficit went up four years in a row. 

In the last two years, my Administration cut the deficit by more than $1.7 trillion. 

The largest deficit reduction in American history.
community_notes:
Tweet is statistically accurate, yet misleading.

1) COVID spending led to huge deficits in 2020 & 2021; its end created the deficit reduction in 2022.

2) However, Biden's other spending increases made the 2022 deficit 41% larger than Trump’s largest non-COVID deficit.

https://fiscaldata.treasury.gov/americas-finance-guide/national-deficit/#us-deficit-by-year
https://www.cnn.com/2023/02/07/politics/fact-check-president-biden-state-of-the-union/index.html
https://www.factcheck.org/2023/02/factchecking-the-state-of-the-union-4/
https://www.nytimes.com/2023/02/07/us/politics/biden-state-of-the-union-fact-check.html
LLM_notes: The post is misleading. The deficit reduction the administration claims is mostly because emergency COVID spending programs expired, not actual policy changes by the current administration. The national debt has still increased significantly, rising from $28.4 trillion to over $31.4 trillion, and the predecessor's deficit increases were driven by pandemic response, not their own policies.
label: T

post: People in Vienna who wear masks on public transport without a medical note will be fined 150 euros. How the tables have turned.
community_notes:
The Austrian Government guidelines explicitly state that medical masks are exempt from such fines. The guidelines prohibit the full concealment of an individual's face. 
For more, please see:
https://www.oesterreich.gv.at/en/themen/leben_in_oesterreich/aufenthalt/Seite.120251.html
LLM_notes: The claim that wearing masks without a medical note in Vienna's public transport will result in a 150-euro fine is incorrect. Austria has a 2017 law banning full face coverings (like burqas), not regular masks. Medical masks are an exception, so wearing them isn't illegal. Also, the mask mandate for public transport ended in February 2023, so there's no current requirement to wear masks, and no specific law targets people for wearing masks without a medical note.
label: T

post:
Louis DeJoy plans to slash 50,000 USPS jobs.
 
Why in the world does Trump's postmaster general still have his job?
 
And how is this not a massive national scandal?
community_notes:
The USPS plans to eliminate 50,000 positions over the next 10 years, against a base of 517,000 employees.  These will be through retirements and other attrition, not through layoffs.  It will allow for modernization and streamlining of the postal service.  
https://www.newsweek.com/usps-plans-cut-50000-jobs-reach-break-even-point-united-states-postal-service-1729372
LLM_notes: Louis DeJoy is not "Trump's postmaster general"—he serves under President Biden, though he was appointed by the U.S. Postal Service Board of Governors, which is filled with Trump appointees, making it hard to fire him. The 50,000 job cuts are planned through attrition over 10 years, not mass layoffs, and the USPS has been losing billions annually for decades due to declining mail demand and inefficiency, not a scandal.
label: P

The closest thing to a "Rothschild Family" business is Rothschild & Co, which is worth about $15 billion. Not a single member of the family is on Forbes' 2023 list of the world's billionaires.

The Rothschilds aren’t even among the top 20 richest families now, and there’s no evidence they control central banks or own majority company stakes. post:
NASA Just Saw Something Come Out Of A Black Hole For The First Time Ever 

https://t.co/dQcTZ9ygTH
community_notes:
Nothing came out of a black hole. A radiation flare was observed from activity in the corona (a region of highly energetic particles surrounding the black hole) around black hole Markarian 335 in 2014.
Original story from 2015: https://www.jpl.nasa.gov/news/black-hole-has-major-flare
LLM_notes: The post claims NASA "just saw something come out of a black hole for the first time ever," but this is inaccurate. The article is from 2015, so "just" is misleading. The event actually happened a long time ago, 324 million years in the past, meaning it’s not the first time it occurred, just the first time observed. Also, it’s not "something coming out"—it’s data analysis of a past event, and mass ejections from black holes have been seen before, so it’s not new.
label: T

https://itcommunity.stanford.edu/news/update-elimination-harmful-language-initiative-stanfords-it-community
LLM_notes: Stanford did not ban the word "American" on its websites. post:
Pretty absurd that chatGPT has passed the United States Medical Licensing Examination (USMLE). 

Today, it takes 4 years of med school and 2+ years of clinical rotations to pass. It tests ambiguous scenarios & closely-related differential diagnoses

https://t.co/oGdKXhEnUt
community_notes:
The cited article (which has not been peer-reviewed) does not conclude that ChatGPT had “passed” the USMLE, as has been stated in this tweet.
Rather, the results approached passing but did not meet/reach it, with accuracy for Step 1 68.0%, Step 2CK 58.3%, and Step 3 62.4%. https://t.co/GGKbYfeUFR
LLM_notes: The post’s claim that passing the USMLE requires 4 years of med school and 2+ years of clinical rotations is incorrect; these are the requirements to be eligible to take the test, not the time to pass it. The USMLE is mostly rote memorization and pattern recognition, not ambiguous clinical scenarios or complex differential diagnoses, as 90% of it is about recalling facts and question patterns, not actual medical understanding. Additionally, ChatGPT did not "pass" the USMLE but only "approached passing performance" (43-68% accuracy), and the test excluded non-text questions (images, sound), limiting its difficulty. Passing the USMLE does not reflect clinical ability, as it is a memory-based exam, not a measure of real-world medical practice.
label: T

post:
Good morning. The US Congress is about to send another $44 billion to Boeing, Raytheon and the CIA "for the war in Ukraine." 

That's a total of $100 billion sent by the US in 10 months.

The entire Russian military budget for the year is $65 billion.

https://t.co/wszK7RHFos
community_notes:
The 44B$ figure largely includes economic and humanitarian aid. 
27.86B$ of the total amount would go directly towards Defense for Ukraine and NATO. The rest would go towards other economic and humanitarian programs to address the devastation caused by the russian war.
https://appropriations.house.gov/sites/democrats.appropriations.house.gov/files/Ukraine%20Supplemental%20Summary%20FY23.pdf
LLM_notes: The $100 billion mentioned is an authorization, not actual funds sent to Ukraine, and includes non-military aid (like to Africa), with only a portion being military support, such as $12.4 billion in military aid. Russia’s military budget is not $65 billion; estimates are higher, with UK intelligence suggesting 117.5 billion pounds ($150 billion+), PPP-adjusted at around $200 billion, and 2023 budget projections of $84 billion. Additionally, most of the U.S. aid goes to U.S. military suppliers like Boeing and Raytheon, not directly to Ukraine, and the comparison to Russia’s budget is misleading as Russia’s spending is higher and the U.S. figure is authorization, not all spent.
label: P

post:
A brain imaging study on over 60,000 people found that the 2 things that aged your brain the most were schizophrenia and weed. 

Far worse than alcohol or cigarettes. 

Stop pretending weed is healthy. https://t.co/VVkKtaAMWH
community_notes:
The screen cap refers to controversial research from 2018, which “appears to prioritize marketing over science.” Also, “no major research institution takes [Daniel Amen’s] SPECT work seriously.” Finally, “the long-term benefits and risks of cannabis use remain unclear.”
https://www.healthline.com/health-news/are-cannabis-abuse-and-accelerated-brain-aging-linked
https://www.washingtonpost.com/lifestyle/magazine/daniel-amen-is-the-most-popular-psychiatrist-in-america-to-most-researchers-and-scientists-thats-a-very-bad-thing/2012/08/07/467ed52c-c540-11e1-8c16-5080b717c13e_story.html
https://www.health.harvard.edu/blog/cognitive-effects-of-long-term-cannabis-use-in-midlife-202206142760
LLM_notes: The post's claim that weed ages the brain more than alcohol or cigarettes is inaccurate. Many commenters question the study's validity, noting it's often unlinkable, lacks proper controls, and relies on correlation rather than causation. Other studies show alcohol and cigarettes are far more harmful, causing more deaths and brain damage. Conflicting studies suggest cannabis is safer for brain structure, and the post's focus on weed being worse than alcohol/cigarettes is unsupported by solid, verifiable studies, with confounding variables like mental health issues or socioeconomic status not considered.
label: P

post:
With every war going all the way back to Vietnam, the press has been heavily integrated with the troops and there's thousands of hours of live video footage. 

In Ukraine, nothing. 

We get no footage, no detailed updates, no graphs explaining how the war is going, who has… https://t.co/YggVV5c5ad
community_notes:
Footage and analysis of the Russian war on Ukraine from multiple media sources including reporters embedded with Ukrainian troops is and has been available.
https://checkyourfact.com/2023/02/01/fact-check-zero-footage-ukrainian-conflict/
https://libguides.pace.edu/ukraine
https://www.indy100.com/news/journalists-reporting-from-ukraine
The U.S. is not conducting combat operations in Ukraine, unlike other conflicts involving the U.S. military.
https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/factcheck/2022/11/14/fact-check-us-military-personnel-ukraine-inspectors-security/8262293001/
LLM_notes: Ukraine's war is actually the most documented in history, with extensive footage, detailed updates, and maps available. There are thousands of hours of video from social media (Twitter, Telegram, Reddit), embedded journalists, and open-source intelligence, showing everything from drone strikes to frontline movements. The post's claim of "nothing" is false; the lack of U.S. troop involvement means there’s no need for U.S.-style embedded press, but Ukraine’s war is widely covered by Ukrainian and Russian sources, journalists, and daily updates online.

post: Twitter is enforcing its long-standing API rules. That may result in some apps not working.

Currently it's all major third party clients not some. Also, it is unknown what long standing rules have been broken as no guidance has been provided to any API partner. And as the tweet notes, these rules have not changed.
https://9to5mac.com/2023/01/17/twitter-disrespect-developers-clients-not-working/
https://developer.twitter.com/en/developer-terms/policy#:~:text=The%20use%20of%20the%20Twitter,people%20to%2C%20violate%20our%20policies.
LLM_notes: The idea that Twitter is enforcing long-standing API rules is inaccurate. The API Development Agreement was actually changed on January 19, while the tweet was posted on January 17, before the rules were updated. Twitter is instead targeting popular third-party apps by enforcing recently added rules without prior communication to developers or users, not long-standing ones.

post:
I'm being told Pfizer spelled backward in Hebrew, means God of plagues.  Who can confirm?

For now, Google says yes until it's scrubbed.
community_notes:
Pfizer spelled backwards is "Rezifp", which has no historical use anywhere, although it can be pronounced similarly to the name of an ancient Hebrew god named "Resheph", the "god of the plague and underworld".
https://www.britannica.com/topic/Resheph
LLM_notes: The claim that Pfizer spelled backward in Hebrew means "God of plagues" is inaccurate. The correct Hebrew name for the ancient West Semitic god of the plague is Resheph, not "rezifp" (the backward spelling of Pfizer). Hebrew is read right to left, so backward English words like "Pfizer" don’t directly translate. Google translate says no, and some commenters note there’s no actual Hebrew meaning for "rezifp," with others confirming it’s a stretch or false. Additionally, Pfizer is a German surname from its founder, not a刻意 chosen secret message.
label: T
